instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.A1990: What is A1990? A1990 is a model number for a 15 inch size MacBook Pro Retina from years Mid 2018, 2019 with EMC3215, that may contain one of these boards depending on the year & configuration: 820-01041, 820-01814..
definitions.820-01041: What is 820-01041? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.A1706: What is A1706? A1706 is a model number for a 13 inch size MacBook Pro Retina from years 2016, Mid 2017 with EMC 3071, that may contain one of these boards depending on the year & configuration: 820-00239, 820-00923..

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1990</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> No Image After Liquid, Board Chimes!
threads.message:
So i've got an <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1990</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> with I think it's  <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01041</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> (will have to double check that) board. It was liquid damaged top area of the board above the cpu. Also the main screen cable was not damaged but the backlight cable which goes from the screen on one side was corroded. I have replaced the connectors on the screen flex and screen board to fix this. 

I've cleaned up all the areas of corrosion I could see, removed and resoldered any IC's which looked questionable as well. Board powers up takes 20V chimes but doesn't output anything to either the internal display or the external one. I'm aware that with the damage on the screen's board itself there may be an issue with the mux chip but that shouldn't affect external display surely? I do not have a known good screen for this model unfortunately - I may have a damaged one from a 2016 15" Macbook Pro but i'm unsure if they are the same?

I suppose it's possible the GPU is fried - there was corrosion around the power circuitry for the CPU/GPU - would the board still chime if this was the case though?

I don't see these T2 based boards very often so i'm really a bit unsure as to what to check next?

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1990</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> No Image After Liquid, Board Chimes!
threads.message:
External monitor is driven by GPU.
Corrosion on its area could damaged it.

You should change <CHIP>U9850</CHIP> and see if still is possible to get video on internal LCD.
<MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1706</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>/7 screens should serve for test.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1990</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> No Image After Liquid, Board Chimes!
threads.message: I've tried an old broken screen from an <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1706</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> - still no picture. I've ordered a new <CHIP>U9850</CHIP> to try - i've done a bit more checking around and am not getting any voltage on L7410 or L7420. I presume these are for the CPU's internal GPU? The other coils are reading normal voltage - cpu ones 0.8V, gpu 0.9v. Both CPU and GPU are heating up as I would expect - the board appears to be trying to boot to something - the touchbar lights up with an ESC key on it and the caps lock lights up when I activate it.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1990</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> No Image After Liquid, Board Chimes!
threads.message:
So the board looks like booted and active, didn't stuck after chime.

iGPU voltage (L7410/20) appears when Intel high graphics load is detected.
Let us know what happens after <CHIP>U9850</CHIP> was changed.
